The Lebesgue Integral*

F.3. The Lebesgue Integral*

In the definitions and propositions below, we assume the presence of a measure space (Ω,F,μ)(Ω,F,μ) (ΩΩ is an arbitrary set, FF is a σσ-algebra on ΩΩ, and μμ is a measure μ:F→Rμ:F→R). We assume below and in the rest of this book that 0⋅∞=00⋅∞=0.

Definition F.3.1. A function f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R is simple if it has finite range, or in other words we can write ff as
f(ω)=∑i=1nciIAi(ω),n∈N,ci∈Rf(ω)=∑i=1nciIAi(ω),n∈N,ci∈R
for some sets Ai⊂ΩAi⊂Ω, i=1,,ni=1,,n (IA(ω)=1IA(ω)=1 if ω∈Aω∈A and 0 otherwise).
Proposition F.1.1. If f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R is a measurable function, then there exists a sequence of simple measurable functions fn:Ω→R,n∈Nfn:Ω→R,n∈N such that
f(ω)≥0f(ω)≤0implies0≤fn(ω)↗f(ω)implies0≥fn(ω)↘f(ω).f(ω)≥0implies0≤fn(ω)↗f(ω)f(ω)≤0implies0≥fn(ω)↘f(ω).
(Recall Definition B.2.12 regarding the notations ↗,↘↗,↘.)
Proof. The sequence of functions
fn(ω)=⎧⎩⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪−n−(k−1)2−n(k−1)2−nn−∞≤f(ω)≤−n−k2−n<f(ω)≤−(k−1)2−n,1≤k≤n2n(k−1)2−n≤f(ω)<k2−n,1≤k≤n2nn≤f(ω)≤+∞fn(ω)={−n−∞≤f(ω)≤−n−(k−1)2−n−k2−n<f(ω)≤−(k−1)2−n,1≤k≤n2n(k−1)2−n(k−1)2−n≤f(ω)<k2−n,1≤k≤n2nnn≤f(ω)≤+∞
has the necessary properties (see the following example for an illustration).
Example F.3.1. In the case of f(x)=x2f(x)=x2, the functions f1f1 and f2f2 in the proof of the above proposition are
f1(ω)f2(ω)=⎧⎩⎨01/210≤f(ω)<1/21/2≤f(ω)<11≤f(ω)≤+∞,=⎧⎩⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪01/42/43/44/45/46/47/420≤f(ω)<1/41/4≤f(ω)<2/42/4≤f(ω)<3/43/4≤f(ω)<4/44/4≤f(ω)<5/45/4≤f(ω)<6/46/4≤f(ω)<7/47/4≤f(ω)<8/42≤f(ω)≤+∞.f1(ω)={00≤f(ω)<1/21/21/2≤f(ω)<111≤f(ω)≤+∞,f2(ω)={00≤f(ω)<1/41/41/4≤f(ω)<2/42/42/4≤f(ω)<3/43/43/4≤f(ω)<4/44/44/4≤f(ω)<5/45/45/4≤f(ω)<6/46/46/4≤f(ω)<7/47/47/4≤f(ω)<8/422≤f(ω)≤+∞.
The figures below illustrate these functions in the case of Ω=RΩ=R.

Definition F.3.2. The Lebesgue integral of a non-negative measurable simple function is
∫E∑i=1nαiIAidμ=def∑i=1nαiμ(Ai∩E),E∈F.∫E∑i=1nαiIAidμ=def∑i=1nαiμ(Ai∩E),E∈F.
Definition F.3.3. The Lebesgue integral of a non-negative measurable function is
∫Efdμ=defsupg∫Egdμ,E∈F,∫Efdμ=defsupg∫Egdμ,E∈F,
where the supremum ranges over all simple measurable functions gg such that 0≤g≤f0≤g≤f.

Note that if ff is a non-negative measurable simple function, there are two possible definitions for ∫Efdμ∫Efdμ (Definition F.3.2 and Definition F.3.3). Fortunately, they both agree as the supremum in the Definition F.3.3 is realized by g=fg=f.

Proposition F.3.2. Let ff be a non-negative measurable function ff.
  1. If f≤gf≤g then ∫Efdμ≤∫Egdμ∫Efdμ≤∫Egdμ.
  2. If A⊂BA⊂B then ∫Afdμ≤∫Bfdμ∫Afdμ≤∫Bfdμ.
  3. If c∈[0,∞)c∈[0,∞) then ∫Ecfdμ=c∫Efdμ∫Ecfdμ=c∫Efdμ.
  4. If f(x)=0f(x)=0 for all x∈Ex∈E then ∫Efdμ=0∫Efdμ=0.
  5. If μ(E)=0μ(E)=0 then ∫Efdμ=0∫Efdμ=0.
  6. ∫Efdμ=∫Ω(IEf)dμ∫Efdμ=∫Ω(IEf)dμ.
Proof. These properties follow directly from Definitions F.3.2-F.3.3. The first property follows from the fact that the supremum in the definition of ∫Efdμ∫Efdμ is less than or equal to the supremum in the definition of ∫Egdμ∫Egdμ. The second property holds since the supremum in the definition of ∫Afdμ∫Afdμ is less than or equal than the supremum in the definition of ∫Bfdμ∫Bfdμ. The third property follows from the fact that the supremum in the definition of ∫Ecfdμ∫Ecfdμ is cc times the supremum in the definition of ∫Efdμ∫Efdμ. The fourth property follows from the fact that the supremum in the definition of ∫Efdμ∫Efdμ can only be the zero function. The fifth property follows since the integrals of all simple functions over EE are zero. The sixth property follows directly from Definitions F.3.2-F.3.3.
Proposition F.3.3. Let (Ω,F,μ)(Ω,F,μ) be a measure space. For two non-negative measurable simple functions s,t:Ω→[0,∞]s,t:Ω→[0,∞], we have
∫Ω(s+t)dμ=∫Ωsdμ+∫Ωtdμ∫Ω(s+t)dμ=∫Ωsdμ+∫Ωtdμ
and ϕ(E)=∫Esdμϕ(E)=∫Esdμ is a measure function on (Ω,F)(Ω,F).
Proof. We assume that s=∑ki=1αiIAis=∑i=1kαiIAi and t=∑li=1βiIBit=∑i=1lβiIBi. For all sets E∈FE∈F, we have ϕ(E)≥0ϕ(E)≥0 and ϕ(∅)=0ϕ(∅)=0. If En,n∈NEn,n∈N is a sequence disjoint sets in FF with ∪nEn=E∪nEn=E then
ϕ(E)=∫E∑i=1kαiIAidμ=∑i=1kαiμ(Ai∩E)=∑i=1k∑n∈Nαiμ(Ai∩En)=∑n∈Nϕ(En),ϕ(E)=∫E∑i=1kαiIAidμ=∑i=1kαiμ(Ai∩E)=∑i=1k∑n∈Nαiμ(Ai∩En)=∑n∈Nϕ(En),
proving that ϕϕ is a measure.

For all Eij=Ai∩BjEij=Ai∩Bj, i=1,,ki=1,,k, j=1,,lj=1,,l

∫Eij(s+t)dμ=(αi+βj)μ(Eij)=∫Eijsdμ+∫Eijtdμ.∫Eij(s+t)dμ=(αi+βj)μ(Eij)=∫Eijsdμ+∫Eijtdμ.
Since ϕϕ is a measure, it is countable additive and so the above equation implies ∫Ω(s+t)dμ=∫Ωsdμ+∫Ωtdμ.∫Ω(s+t)dμ=∫Ωsdμ+∫Ωtdμ.

Proposition F.3.4 (Monotone Convergence Theorem).
0≤fn↗fimplies∫Ωfndμ↗∫Ωfdμ.0≤fn↗fimplies∫Ωfndμ↗∫Ωfdμ.
Proof. The function f=limfnf=limfn is measurable by Proposition E.6.4, and since ∫fndμ↗∫fndμ↗, we have ∫fndμ↗α∫fndμ↗α for some α∈[0,+∞]α∈[0,+∞] (see Proposition B.2.1). Since fn≤limfnfn≤limfn, we have ∫fndμ≤∫Ωlimn→∞fndμ∫fndμ≤∫Ωlimn→∞fndμ.

It remains to show the reverse inequality ∫fndμ≥∫Ωlimn→∞fndμ∫fndμ≥∫Ωlimn→∞fndμ. For any non-negative simple measurable function ss such that s≤limfns≤limfn and any c∈(0,1)c∈(0,1) we define En={x:fn(x)≥cs(x)},n∈NEn={x:fn(x)≥cs(x)},n∈N. Note that En∈FEn∈F, En↗En↗, and Ω=∪nEnΩ=∪nEn. By definition of EnEn, we have for all n∈Nn∈N

∫Ωfndμ≥∫Enfndμ≥c∫Ensdμ.∫Ωfndμ≥∫Enfndμ≥c∫Ensdμ.
We let n→∞n→∞ and recall that ∫Ensdμ∫Ensdμ is a measure (Proposition F.3.3) ϕ(En)ϕ(En), which converges by Proposition E.2.1 to ϕ(Ω)ϕ(Ω). This implies that
lim∫Ωfndμ≥limc∫Ensdμ=c∫Ωsdμ.lim∫Ωfndμ≥limc∫Ensdμ=c∫Ωsdμ.
Since this holds for any c∈(0,1)c∈(0,1) we also have
lim∫Ωfndμ≥∫Ωsdμ.lim∫Ωfndμ≥∫Ωsdμ.
Finally, since this holds for all non-negative simple measurable function ss such that s≤limfns≤limfn, it also holds for their supremum, which defines the integral ∫Ωlimfndμ∫Ωlimfndμ.

Corollary F.3.1. Let fn,n∈Nfn,n∈N be a sequence of non-negative measurable functions whose sum ∑∞n=1fn(x)∑n=1∞fn(x) converges for all xx. Then
∫Ω∑n=1∞fndμ=∑n=1∞∫Ωfndμ.∫Ω∑n=1∞fndμ=∑n=1∞∫Ωfndμ.
Proof. We first prove this result for a sum of two functions f1+f2f1+f2. Let sksk and tktk be the sequence of measurable functions that converge to f1f1 and f2f2 as in Proposition F.3.1. Then the sequence of simple functions sk+tksk+tk converge to f1+f2f1+f2, and using the Monotone Convergence Theorem above together with Proposition F.3.3, we have
∫Ωf1+f2dμ=∫Ωlimk(sk+tk)dμ=limk∫Ωsk+tkdμ=limk∫Ωskdμ+limk∫Ωtkdμ=∫Ωf1dμ+∫Ωf2dμ.∫Ωf1+f2dμ=∫Ωlimk(sk+tk)dμ=limk∫Ωsk+tkdμ=limk∫Ωskdμ+limk∫Ωtkdμ=∫Ωf1dμ+∫Ωf2dμ.
By induction, we establish the result for a sum of NN functions. Defining gN=∑Nn=1fngN=∑n=1Nfn, we have that gN↗∑∞n=1fngN↗∑n=1∞fn. Applying the Monotone Convergence Theorem again yields
∫Ω∑n=1∞fndμ=∫ΩlimN→∞gNdμ=limN→∞∫ΩgNdμ=limN→∞∑n=1N∫Ωfndμ=∑n=1∞∫Ωfndμ.∫Ω∑n=1∞fndμ=∫ΩlimN→∞gNdμ=limN→∞∫ΩgNdμ=limN→∞∑n=1N∫Ωfndμ=∑n=1∞∫Ωfndμ.
Proposition F.3.5. Let (Ω,F,μ)(Ω,F,μ) be a measure space. For any two non-negative measurable functions f,g:Ω→[0,∞]f,g:Ω→[0,∞],
  1. ϕ(E)=∫Efdμϕ(E)=∫Efdμ is a measure function on (Ω,F)(Ω,F), and
  2. ∫Ωgdϕ=∫Ωgfdμ.∫Ωgdϕ=∫Ωgfdμ.
We say in this case that ϕϕ has a density ff with respect to μμ, and write dϕ=fdμdϕ=fdμ.
Proof. It is easy to see that ϕ(E)≥0ϕ(E)≥0 for all E∈FE∈F and ϕ(∅)=0ϕ(∅)=0. We next show that ϕϕ is countable additive. Let En,n∈NEn,n∈N be a sequence of disjoint sets whose union equals EE. Corollary F.3.1 implies that
ϕ(E)=∫ΩfIEdμ=∫Ω∑n=1∞fIEndμ=∑n=1∞∫fIEndμ=∑n=1∞ϕ(En).(*)(*)ϕ(E)=∫ΩfIEdμ=∫Ω∑n=1∞fIEndμ=∑n=1∞∫fIEndμ=∑n=1∞ϕ(En).
The second statement above follows from the first statement whenever gg is an indicator function g(x)=cIA(x)g(x)=cIA(x). Similar arguments show that the second statement follows from the first statement whenever gg is a simple function. The case of a general function gg follows from approximating gg by a sequence of simple functions 0≤s1≤s2≤⋯0≤s1≤s2≤⋯ (Proposition F.3.1) and using the Monotone Convergence Theorem twice
∫Ωgdϕ=∫Ωlimnsndϕ=limn∫Ωsndϕ=limn∫Ωsnfdμ=∫Ωgfdμ.∫Ωgdϕ=∫Ωlimnsndϕ=limn∫Ωsndϕ=limn∫Ωsnfdμ=∫Ωgfdμ.
Proposition F.3.6 (Fatou's Lemma). For any sequence of non-negative measurable functions fn,n∈Nfn,n∈N,
∫Ωlim infn→∞fndμ≤lim infn→∞∫Ωfndμ.∫Ωlim infn→∞fndμ≤lim infn→∞∫Ωfndμ.
Proof. Defining the function gk(x)=inf{fi(x):i≥k}gk(x)=inf{fi(x):i≥k}, we have gk≤fkgk≤fk and therefore for all k∈Nk∈N,
∫Ωgkdμ≤∫Ωfkdμ.∫Ωgkdμ≤∫Ωfkdμ.
Since 0≤g1≤g2≤⋯0≤g1≤g2≤⋯, and gk→lim infnfngk→lim infnfn, we can apply the Monotone convergence theorem to the left hand side above to get
∫Ωlim infnfndμ=limk∫Ωgkdμ=lim infk∫Ωgkdμ≤lim infk∫Ωfkdμ.∫Ωlim infnfndμ=limk∫Ωgkdμ=lim infk∫Ωgkdμ≤lim infk∫Ωfkdμ.

The definition of the Lebesgue integral ∫Afdμ∫Afdμ thus far has been restricted to non-negative functions ff. We generalize this below to real valued functions f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R.

Definition F.3.4. For a function f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R we define its positive and negative parts
f+(ω)f−(ω)={f(ω)0f(ω)≥0f(ω)<0={−f(ω)0f(ω)≤0f(ω)>0.f+(ω)={f(ω)f(ω)≥00f(ω)<0f−(ω)={−f(ω)f(ω)≤00f(ω)>0.
This implies the following decomposition of an arbitrary function f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R to its positive and negative parts:
f(ω)=f++f−.f(ω)=f++f−.
Definition F.3.5. The Lebesgue integral of a measurable function f:Ω→Rf:Ω→R is
∫Ωfdμ=def∫Ωf+dμ−∫Ωf−dμ∫Ωfdμ=def∫Ωf+dμ−∫Ωf−dμ
where ∫f+dμ∫f+dμ and ∫f−dμ∫f−dμ are integrals of non-negative functions defined in Definition F.3.3. If the integral above is finite we say that ff is μμ-integrable or simply integrable.

If both ∫f+dμ=∞∫f+dμ=∞ and ∫f−dμ=∞∫f−dμ=∞ in the definition above we say that the integral above does not exist.

Proposition F.3.7.
∣∣∫Ωfdμ∣∣≤∫Ω|f|dμ.|∫Ωfdμ|≤∫Ω|f|dμ.
Proof. The left hand side equals ∫f+dμ−∫f−dμ∫f+dμ−∫f−dμ, a difference of two non-negative quantities. This is clearly smaller than the right hand side, which equals ∫|f+|dμ+∫|f−|dμ∫|f+|dμ+∫|f−|dμ.
Proposition F.3.8. Let f,gf,g be two measurable functions and α,β∈Rα,β∈R. Then
∫Ωαf+βgdμ=α∫Ωfdμ+β∫Ωgdμ.∫Ωαf+βgdμ=α∫Ωfdμ+β∫Ωgdμ.
Proof. We decompose the proof into the case ∫Ωf+gdμ=∫Ωfdμ+∫Ωgdμ∫Ωf+gdμ=∫Ωfdμ+∫Ωgdμ and the case ∫Ωαfdμ=α∫Ωfdμ∫Ωαfdμ=α∫Ωfdμ. Both cases together imply the proposition above.

In the first case, if α>0α>0 the result follows from applying Corollary F.3.1 to the positive-negative decomposition

∫αfdμ=∫(αf)+dμ−∫(αf)−dμ=α∫f+dμ−α∫f−dμ=α∫fdμ.∫αfdμ=∫(αf)+dμ−∫(αf)−dμ=α∫f+dμ−α∫f−dμ=α∫fdμ.
Similarly, if α<0α<0
∫αfdμ=∫(αf)+dμ−∫(αf)−dμ=∫(−αf−)dμ−∫(−αf+)dμ=−α∫f−dμ−(−α)∫f+dμ=α∫fdμ.∫αfdμ=∫(αf)+dμ−∫(αf)−dμ=∫(−αf−)dμ−∫(−αf+)dμ=−α∫f−dμ−(−α)∫f+dμ=α∫fdμ.
In the second case, the result follows from applying Corollary F.3.1 to the positive-negative decomposition of f+gf+g
∫f+gdμ=∫f+−f−+g+−g−dμ=∫f+dμ−∫f−dμ+∫g+dμ−∫g−dμ=∫fdμ+∫gdμ.∫f+gdμ=∫f+−f−+g+−g−dμ=∫f+dμ−∫f−dμ+∫g+dμ−∫g−dμ=∫fdμ+∫gdμ.

Proposition F.3.9 (Dominated Convergence Theorem). If fn→ffn→f and |fn(x)|≤g(x)|fn(x)|≤g(x) for all n∈Nn∈N for some integrable function gg, then
∫Ω∣∣fn−f∣∣dμ→0∫Ωfndμ→∫Ωfdμ.∫Ω|fn−f|dμ→0∫Ωfndμ→∫Ωfdμ.
Proof. We denote f=limfnf=limfn and observe that fnfn is integrable since |fn|≤g|fn|≤g and gg is integrable. Applying Fatou's lemma to the sequence of non-negative functions 2g−|fn−f|≥02g−|fn−f|≥0 we get

Corollary F.3.2 (Bounded Convergence Theorem). If μ(Ω)<∞μ(Ω)<∞, fn→ffn→f, and for some finite MM, |fn(x)|<M|fn(x)|<M for all nn and all xx, then
∫Ωfndμ→∫Ωfdμ.∫Ωfndμ→∫Ωfdμ.
Proof. The result follows immediately from the second statement of the dominated convergence theorem above.

Most of the propositions in this section are specified in terms of an integral of a function ff over the measurable space ΩΩ. These propositions remain true if the integrand ff is replaced by fIAfIA, effectively creating new versions of these propositions where the integrals range over alternative sets AA rather than ΩΩ. ∫Aαf+βgdμ=α∫Afdμ+β∫Agdμ.∫Aαf+βgdμ=α∫Afdμ+β∫Agdμ.

Definition F.3.6 Let (Ω,F,μ)(Ω,F,μ) be a measure space. We say that a property holds almost everywhere, abbreviated a.e., if it holds on Ω∖SΩ∖S where μ(S)=0μ(S)=0. In other words, the property holds everywhere except on a set of measure zero.

F.3.1 Relation between the Riemann and the Lebesgue Integrals*

The following proposition states precisely when a function is Riemann integrable. It also states that if the Riemann integral exists then the Lebesgue integral exists as well and the two integrals agree in value.

Proposition F.3.11. Let f:[a,b]→Rf:[a,b]→R be a bounded function. Then it is Riemann integrable if and only if it is continuous a.e.. Furthermore, ff then is also integrable with respect to the Lebesgue measure, and the two integrals agree in value.
Proof. We use notations below from the section concerning Riemann integrals. To distinguish between the Riemann and the Lebesgue integrals we denote the former as ∫fdx∫fdx and the latter as ∫fdμ∫fdμ (μμ here corresponds to the Lebesgue measure). All integrals in the proof below are over the interval [a,b][a,b].

We construct a sequence of partitions Pn,n∈NPn,n∈N such that PkPk is a refinement of Pk−1Pk−1, the distance between adjacent points in PkPk is less than 1/k1/k, and

limk→∞U(Pk,f)limk→∞L(Pk,f)=∫fdx=∫fdx−−−−−−.limk→∞U(Pk,f)=∫fdxlimk→∞L(Pk,f)=∫fdx_.
(This is possible since the lower and upper Riemann integrals are defined using the limits above.) Defining the following two simple functions
L(x)U(x)=⎧⎩⎨mif(a)f(b)x∈Δix=ax=b=⎧⎩⎨Mif(a)f(b)x∈Δix=ax=b.L(x)={mix∈Δif(a)x=af(b)x=bU(x)={Mix∈Δif(a)x=af(b)x=b.
we have
L(Pk,f)U(Pk,f)L1≤L2≤⋯≤=∫Lkdμ=∫Ukdμf≤⋯≤U2≤Ul(since Pk refines Pk−1).L(Pk,f)=∫LkdμU(Pk,f)=∫UkdμL1≤L2≤⋯≤f≤⋯≤U2≤Ul(since Pk refines Pk−1).
The last equation above implies that LkLk and UkUk converge to limit functions L(x)=limn→∞Lk(x)L(x)=limn→∞Lk(x) and U(x)=limn→∞Uk(x)U(x)=limn→∞Uk(x) and that L≤f≤UL≤f≤U. Using the Monotone Convergence Theorem, we have
∫Ldμ=∫fdx−−−−−−,∫Udμ=∫fdx.∫Ldμ=∫fdx_,∫Udμ=∫fdx.

Note that the above derivations assume only that ff is bounded. The function ff is Riemann integrable, if and only if the lower and upper integrals agree, which occurs if and only if L=UL=U a.e. (using the fact that U−L≥0U−L≥0 and Proposition F.3.10) or equivalently L=f=UL=f=U. This proves that if ff is a bounded Riemann integrable function, it is also Lebesgue integrable with respect to the Lebesgue measure and the two integrals agree.

If xx is not equal to one of the points in the partition PkPk, then L(x)=U(x)L(x)=U(x) if and only if mi=Mimi=Mi, which occurs if and only if ff is continuous at xx. Recalling that ff is Riemann integrable if and only if L=UL=U a.e. (shown above), we have that ff is Riemann integrable if and only if ff is continuous a.e..

F.3.2 Transformed Measures*

Definition F.3.7. Consider a measure space (Ω,F,μ)(Ω,F,μ), and a measurable function T:Ω→Ω′T:Ω→Ω′ where (Ω′,F′)(Ω′,F′) is a measurable space. The transformed measure μT−1μT−1 is a measure on (Ω′,F′)(Ω′,F′) defined as follows
μT−1(A)=μ(T−1A),A∈F′.μT−1(A)=μ(T−1A),A∈F′.

It is straightforward to verify that μT−1μT−1 satisfy the conditions of non-negativity and countable additivity, and is therefore a legitimate measure function. The following proposition uses this concept to construct the well-known change of variable formula for the Lebesgue integral.

Proposition F.3.12 (Change of Variable). Let f:Ω′→Rf:Ω′→R be a non-negative measurable function. Then
∫T−1(A′)f(Tx)μ(dx)=∫A′f(x′)μT−1(dx′),A∈Ω′.(**)(**)∫T−1(A′)f(Tx)μ(dx)=∫A′f(x′)μT−1(dx′),A∈Ω′.
The change of variable formula above holds also for a real valued ff (not necessarily non-negative) if f∘Tf∘T is integrable with respect to μμ.
Proof. If f=IAf=IA then f∘T=IT−1Af∘T=IT−1A and (**) holds by definition of the Lebesgue integral and the transformed measure. The linearity of the integral implies that (**) holds also for non-negative simple function. The change of variable formula (**) holds for non-negative function by constructing a sequence of simple functions sn,n∈Nsn,n∈N such that sn↗fsn↗f and using the Monotone Convergence Theorem.

If ff is a real valued function, we can apply (**) to |f||f|, which implies that ff is integrable with respect to μT−1μT−1 if f∘Tf∘T is integrable with respect to μμ. The result then follows by decomposing ff to its positive and negative parts and using the first part of the proposition on these two non-negative functions.

Proposition F.2.3 derives a special case of the change of variables formula that is often useful in computing non-trivial integrals.
